annotation.spannedText: reports from a March meeting of the World Health Organization

classMention.mentionClass: reports from a March meeting of the World Health Organization

annotation.spannedText: “There’s no evidence that any recent vector-­control interventions, including massive spraying of insecticides, have had any significant effect on dengue transmission.”

classMention.mentionClass: “There’s no evidence that any recent vector-­control interventions, including massive spraying of insecticides, have had any significant effect on dengue transmission.”

annotation.spannedText: “I’m very optimistic — and I say this not just because I’ve been working on this for 16 years,”

classMention.mentionClass: “I’m very optimistic — and I say this not just because I’ve been working on this for 16 years,”

annotation.spannedText: Anna Durbin, a dengue vaccine researcher at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

classMention.mentionClass: Anna Durbin, a dengue vaccine researcher at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

annotation.spannedText: “In 95 percent of people who have very severe disease, it’s because they’ve gotten a second infection of a different type,” ... “If you get infected with dengue 1, and five years later you get another dengue 1, we believe you’ll be protected. If you get infected with dengue 2, there are biological processes that increase your chances of severe disease.”

classMention.mentionClass: “In 95 percent of people who have very severe disease, it’s because they’ve gotten a second infection of a different type,” ... “If you get infected with dengue 1, and five years later you get another dengue 1, we believe you’ll be protected. If you get infected with dengue 2, there are biological processes that increase your chances of severe disease.”

annotation.spannedText: Stephen Thomas of the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, Md

classMention.mentionClass: Stephen Thomas of the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, Md

annotation.spannedText: if a vaccine works even just a little bit, it’s better than nothing

classMention.mentionClass: if a vaccine works even just a little bit, it’s better than nothing

annotation.spannedText: “Most people say if a vaccine works even just a little bit, it’s better than nothing,” ... In the case of dengue, however, “a bad vaccine can be worse than no vaccine. You may actually predispose people to more severe disease.”

classMention.mentionClass: “Most people say if a vaccine works even just a little bit, it’s better than nothing,” ... In the case of dengue, however, “a bad vaccine can be worse than no vaccine. You may actually predispose people to more severe disease.”

annotation.spannedText: that the immune response from the vaccine mimicked a first infection in some of the littlest patients, predisposing them to the dangers of a second round of illness

classMention.mentionClass: that the immune response from the vaccine mimicked a first infection in some of the littlest patients, predisposing them to the dangers of a second round of illness

annotation.spannedText: ‘Are we going to protect people from dengue 2?’

classMention.mentionClass: ‘Are we going to protect people from dengue 2?’

annotation.spannedText: “We knew the dengue 2 component was weaker,” ... “Our question was, ‘Are we going to protect people from dengue 2?’ Challenge study said ‘yes.’ ”

classMention.mentionClass: “We knew the dengue 2 component was weaker,” ... “Our question was, ‘Are we going to protect people from dengue 2?’ Challenge study said ‘yes.’ ”

annotation.spannedText: that dengue and Zika may be partners in crime, interacting in some way that allows the Zika virus to cross the placenta

annotation.spannedText: “We were surprised when we saw what a devastating disease it was,” ... “Why do we have it? We still don’t know.”

annotation.spannedText: Jorge Kalil, director of the Butantan Institute in São Paulo, Brazil’s premier institution for vaccine research and development

classMention.mentionClass: Jorge Kalil, director of the Butantan Institute in São Paulo, Brazil’s premier institution for vaccine research and development

annotation.spannedText: “It’s like you’re making your own viruslike particle,”

classMention.mentionClass: “It’s like you’re making your own viruslike particle,”

annotation.spannedText: Julie Ledgerwood, chief of the clinical trials program at the NIH’s vaccine research center

classMention.mentionClass: Julie Ledgerwood, chief of the clinical trials program at the NIH’s vaccine research center

annotation.spannedText: that Butantan researchers in Brazil need options sooner, especially for pregnant women

annotation.spannedText: to develop antibodies in response to a vaccine

annotation.spannedText: It’s an unorthodox approach ... but his agency feels an urgency to protect infants who can’t wait for the vaccine research to run its course

annotation.spannedText: “It’s very basic, and we know it is safe,” ... because the virus is dead

annotation.spannedText: one infection from chikungunya leaves lasting protection

annotation.spannedText: More than 15 different chikungunya vaccines are in various stages of development, employing almost every known approach to vaccine innovation

annotation.spannedText: “Chikungunya is not going away,” ... “We are on the back end of the current epidemic, but there will be another one coming, and we hope to have a vaccine ready in time.”

annotation.spannedText: that the spread of Zika, dengue and chikungunya are the price being paid for policies that dropped the ball on mosquito and disease control
